docs.lead_paragraph: Nine people were charged yesterday in Manhattan federal court with conspiracy to commit fraud after staging two car accidents and collecting money for bogus injuries and damages from health care and automobile insurance companies, said James B. Comey, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Those accused include the owners of a Brooklyn auto repair shop, various health care providers, an insurance broker and the manager of two Brooklyn medical clinics, Mr. Comey said. The defendants each face up to five years in prison and a fine of roughly $250,000 if convicted. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9 Accused Of Insurance Fraud

docs.abstract: Nine people are charged with conspiracy to commit fraud after attempting to collect money from health care and auto insurance agencies for fake injuries (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: TO talk. To be listened to. To unwind. To be touched. When you are a low-income woman with cancer, and you live in the margins, it is often the little things -- a caring touch, a steaming cup of herbal tea -- that can make a difference.

headline.main: Providing the Little Things That Mean the Most

docs.abstract: Charlotte Maxwell Clinic in Oakland, Calif, provides free alternative medicine treatment, including massage and acupuncture, to poor women with cancer, including more and more homeless women; photos (M) (Special section, Giving)

docs.lead_paragraph: F.B.I. agents raided the headquarters of National Century Financial Enterprises Inc. in Dublin, Ohio, on Saturday, seizing the books and computer records of the troubled health care finance company. The raid came as the company has been struggling with financial problems that began in late October and that may force it to file for bankruptcy as early as today.

headline.main: F.B.I. Raids Headquarters of Health Services Lender

docs.abstract: FBI agents raid headquarters of National Century Financial Enterprises, seizing books and computer records; company may be forced to file for bankruptcy as early as Nov 18 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LOUISE LANDAU, 95, is not a trendy person. But she recently decided that the hottest thing in giving -- a charitable gift annuity -- was the perfect vehicle for her most recent round of philanthropy. Mrs. Landau lives outside Chicago. A retired businesswoman -- ''I made the money all myself'' she said -- she has long donated substantial sums to local charities like Chicago Commons, which operates a health center named in her honor.

headline.main: Give It All Away, and Get Set for Life

docs.abstract: More and more charities are offering gift annuities, which have advantages for both organizations and donors, including favorable rate of return and tax deduction; estimated 4,000 to 5,000 charities nationwide now offer gift annuities; drawing (M) (Special section, Giving)

docs.lead_paragraph: It's Back to the Table, If Indeed There Is One To the owner of the opulent restaurant, the prospect of a unionized work force was as appetizing as a dish of rotting ragout. To the workers demanding unionization, his concern for them was as solid as a crumbling loaf of moldy bread. Such were the ingredients in one of the longest strikes in New York City in years, a four-year standoff in the 1990's between the owner of the Box Tree restaurant on Manhattan's East Side, and picketing workers and the union they wanted to represent them.
docs.abstract: Following Up column; former Box Tree restaurant, which endured four-year strike by employees in 1990's and finally closed in May, will become high-end kosher French steakhouse; Jeff Koons's sculpture Puppy, which was on public display in Rockefeller Center in 2000, is now part of private collection, but owner prefers anonymity; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On a warm, breezy Friday in September, a parade of mothers in minivans arrived at a preschool in suburban Connecticut to drop off a collection of 4-year-olds. Among the young students was Sam G., a sturdy, big-eared boy with cheeks that flush easily and a personality that has earned him a reputation, politely speaking, as a handful. Like most 4-year-old boys, Sam loves things that move -- trains, planes and trucks, especially fire trucks -- and is usually on the move himself. When he enters a room, his clear blue eyes dart about, as though he cannot take in the sights fast enough. His knees and elbows are perpetually scraped. When his teachers read stories aloud, Sam often wanders about.
docs.abstract: Sheryl Gay Stolberg article on three-year federal financed study on safety and effectiveness of methylphenidate (Ritalin) on preschoolers with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; focuses 4-year-old boy from suburban Connecticut who is participating in study; Steven Hyman, former director of National Institute of Mental Health, defends study, perhaps most controversial medical experiment ever conducted in children by federal government, on ground that so many preschoolers are already on drug even though it is not approved for children under age 6; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Lynne Allen and Michael Haran Lanza were married yesterday at the Arlington Street Church in Boston. The Rev. George Whitehouse, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, 39, and the bridegroom, 40, met in the 1980's at the University of Connecticut, from which they graduated.

docs.lead_paragraph: GETTING sick while traveling is one of the quickest ways to ruin a vacation, which is why most advice about travel and health care focuses on prevention. But despite the most stringent precautions, illnesses and injuries do happen, raising the problem of finding a doctor on the road. While many medical situations can be taken care of by a trip to a drugstore and others obviously require a call to 911 or its equivalent, it is the gray area in between that challenges travelers to be a bit more resourceful.
docs.abstract: Susan Stellin Practical Traveler column offers advice on finding doctors while traveling abroad; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A few miles off the highway in this secluded town stands a sprawling nursing home that has become a virtual annex to New York State's psychiatric system. Confined on the third floor of the home, which has no mental health credentials and has been admonished by New Jersey officials for providing inadequate care, are more than 125 people who were sent here by state psychiatric hospitals in New York. Locked away at a similarly checkered nursing home near a cornfield in Andover Township, N.J., about 50 miles from Manhattan, are more than 200 other former New York psychiatric patients. Still others just like them have been sent by New York officials to problem-plagued nursing homes and adult homes as far-flung as the Boston area, including several deemed so violent and disastrous that Massachusetts officials threatened to close them down. At one last year, a resident from New York gouged out the eye of another resident with his bare hands, the officials said.

headline.main: New York Exports Mentally Ill, Shifting Burden to Other States

docs.abstract: Pataki administration has been exporting hundreds of New York State's most troubled psychiatric patients to other states over past eight years, turning over responsibility for their care to nursing homes that have little if any expertise and often have tarnished histories; many patients have been rejected by private facilities in New York because of high level of care they need; out-of-state homes have reaped hundreds of millions of dollars from New York Medicaid program, which typically pays for residents' care; New York saves money because federal government, which heavily subsidizes Medicaid, would not cover any costs if patients were in its own state psychiatric hospitals; Pataki's assertion during re-election campaign that his administration has brought back 5,000 mentally ill patients cannot be substantiated by New York Medicaid records; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq, Dow and S.&P. 500 Post Gains for the Week Stocks inched higher as consumer confidence rose in November. Key gauges registered gains for the week despite another terror attack warning. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.38 point, to 1,411.14. It finished up 3.8 percent for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.96 points, to 8,579.09. It was up 0.5 percent for the week, its sixth consecutive gain. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index index climbed 5.56 points, to 909.83, and rose 1.7 percent for the week. [Page C4.]
